fullProgramDescription: The Political Science major at MIT is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the discipline, covering topics such as political theory, international relations, comparative politics, and American politics. The program emphasizes theoretical and empirical approaches, preparing students for a range of careers in government, law, academia, and other fields.
shortProgramDescription: The Political Science major at MIT provides a rigorous education in the field, emphasizing both theoretical foundations and empirical analysis.
classHighlights: The core courses, including 17.20 Introduction to Political Science Research Methods and 17.21 Comparative Politics or 17.22 International Relations, provide a foundation in the discipline.
Students choose from a range of elective courses, such as 17.30 Public Policy, 17.31 American Politics, and 17.50 Political Theory, to explore specific areas of interest.
Upper-level courses, including 17.801 Quantitative Research Methods and 17.802 Advanced Research Methods, develop advanced research skills and theoretical knowledge.
learningOutcomes: Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the major subfields within political science.
Apply theoretical and empirical approaches to analyze political phenomena.
Conduct original research using appropriate methodologies.
Evaluate and synthesize complex information from a variety of sources.
Communicate effectively in written and oral forms.
creditRequirements: 180-192 units (typically 4-5 courses per semester, semester system)
additionalInformation: Students must fulfill the General Institute Requirements and complete a minimum of 12 subjects in the Political Science major, with at least 9 at the 17.30 level or above.
